questionnaire.title: bioRxiv preprints: a survey on motivations and selection strategies

questionnaireInfo.text:
Dear participant,

Thank you for visiting this survey. My name is Nicholas Fraser, I am a postdoctoral researcher in the field of bibliometrics at the Leibniz Information Center for Economics, Kiel, Germany (https://www.zbw.eu).

You have been contacted because your email address was listed as a corresponding email address for a preprint deposited on bioRxiv (https://www.biorxiv.org). In the following survey, I will ask you some questions related to your strategies and motivations for selecting scientific articles to deposit as preprints. This study is being conducted as part of a wider project to understand the factors influencing the impact of making scientific papers openly accessible.

The survey should take approximately 10 minutes to complete.

If you have any questions or concerns regarding this survey, please contact me directly at n.fraser@zbw.eu.

I appreciate your time and input.

Nicholas Fraser

 

Privacy Policy

You have received this survey because your email address is listed as the corresponding email address for a preprint deposited on bioRxiv (https://www.biorxiv.org). Please note that myself and my collaborators in this study are independent researchers and that this survey is not affiliated with bioRxiv or its operator, Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory (https://www.cshl.edu). Your participation in this survey is entirely voluntary, and you may leave at any time. The survey responses gathered here are completely anonymous. The response data will be stored on a server that is maintained by the University of Kiel, Germany. The survey questions and response data will subsequently be published (in fully anonymised form) on the open access research repository Zenodo (https://zenodo.org).

Thank you for participating. Should you have any questions, comments or concerns regarding this survey, please contact me directly at n.fraser@zbw.eu.

Nicholas Fraser

question.text: Please select your current country of residence:

category.label: The former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia
the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

question.text: Please select your main scientific discipline(s):

directive.text: Note: disciplines listed here conform to the main subject areas listed on bioRxiv

question.text: Please select your gender:
Please select your current career status:
Please select your current institution type:
How many articles have you published in a scientific journal <u>as a corresponding author</u> in the past 5 years?
With respect to articles that you have published in a scientific journal as a corresponding author in the past 5 years, please select which statement applies:

directive.text: * Here we define a preprint as a version of a scientific article that is deposited to an open, online repository (not limited to bioRxiv) at any point prior to acceptance for publication in a scientific journal.

category.label: All of these articles were also deposited as preprints*
Some of these articles were also deposited as preprints*
None of these articles were also deposited as preprints*

subQuestion.text: The articles that were deposited as preprints were of a higher scientific quality than those that were not deposited as preprints
The articles that were deposited as preprints contained more exciting/novel results than those that were not deposited as preprints
The articles that were deposited as preprints had a greater societal value/significance than those that were not deposited as preprints
The articles that were deposited as preprints were published in journals with higher impact factors than those not deposited as preprints
I expected the articles that were deposited as preprints to receive more citations than those not deposited as preprints
I expected the articles that were deposited as preprints to be disseminated more widely online (e.g. on social media) than those not deposited as preprints

question.text: (Optional) Were there any other differences between the articles you chose to deposit as preprints versus those you did not deposit, or differences in your expections for how the articles would be received in your community?
Considering only the articles that were deposited as preprints, please select your level of agreement with the following statements:

subQuestion.text: The decision to deposit articles as preprints was the free decision of the author(s)
It was necessary to deposit articles as preprints to comply with an institutional open access/preprint policy
It was necessary to deposit articles as preprints to comply with a funding agency's open access/preprint policy
It was usually my suggestion to deposit articles as preprints
It was usually my co-authors suggestion to deposit articles as preprints
Preprints were deposited to increase awareness of my/our research
Preprints were deposited to stake a priority claim on my/our findings
Preprints were deposited to benefit the scientific enterprise
Preprints were deposited to receive more feedback on my/our work
Preprints were deposited to share my/our findings more quickly
Depositing preprints had positive benefits in terms of citations
Depositing preprints had positive benefits in terms of other forms of online dissemination (e.g. sharing on social media)
The decision to deposit articles as preprints was the free decision of the author(s)
It was necessary to deposit articles as preprints to comply with an institutional open access/preprint policy
It was necessary to deposit articles as preprints to comply with a funding agency's open access/preprint policy
It was usually my suggestion to deposit articles as preprints
It was usually my co-authors suggestion to deposit articles as preprints
Preprints were deposited to increase awareness of my/our research
Preprints were deposited to stake a priority claim on my/our findings
Preprints were deposited to benefit the scientific enterprise
Preprints were deposited to receive more feedback on my/our work
Preprints were deposited to share my/our findings more quickly
Depositing preprints had positive benefits in terms of citations
Depositing preprints had positive benefits in terms of other forms of online dissemination (e.g. sharing on social media)

question.text: (Optional) Were there any additional reasons that motivated you to deposit these articles as preprints?
Considering only the articles that <u>were not</u> deposited as preprints, please select your level of agreement with the following statements:

subQuestion.text: I was unaware of the option to deposit preprints at that time
The journal(s) I wanted to submit to did not allow prior posting of preprints
I was not allowed to deposit these articles as preprints (e.g. due to institutional or funding agency policies)
I did not want to deposit these articles as preprints
I wanted to deposit these articles as preprints but my co-authors disagreed
Depositing a preprint would have had negative effects for my/our research
I did not want anyone else to see my/our preprint and publish before us
My/our findings were controversial and needed to be evaluated by peer-review before being published
My/our work did not fit within the scope of any preprint repository
I was unaware of the option to deposit preprints at that time

I did not want anyone else to see my/our preprint and publish before us
My/our findings were controversial and needed to be evaluated by peer-review before being published
My/our work did not fit within the scope of any preprint repository

(Optional) Please provide any additional feedback on this survey:
Would you be like to be contacted to be notified of eventual results of this study, or be interested in participating in future follow-up studies?

category.label: Yes, please contact me to inform me when the study results are available
Yes, I would be interested in participating in future follow-up studies

question.text: Please provide your email address below to be contacted. Email addresses will be treated confidentially and removed from any published datasets resulting from this study.
